awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Towards a Generalized Microkinetic Description of Lignin Liquefaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Lignin is an abundant natural resource whose higher carbon content, when compared to cellulose and hemicellulose, makes it a very attractive renewable feedstock for producing fuels and chemicals. Lignin liquefaction is a promising process for converting this underutilized resource into monomeric phenols that can be easily upgraded to fuels and chemicals, but the underlying chemical kinetic processes are not well understood. This collaborative research project aims to develop a rational framework that integrates modelling and experimental tools to explicitly account for lignin and its oligomeric intermediate chemical structures at relevant liquefaction conditions in the presence or absence of solvents.

Lignin liquefaction can be conducted in aqueous environments (hydrothermal liquefaction), in organic solvents (solvolysis), in ionic liquids or in solvent free conditions (pyrolysis). Assigning a realistic chemical formula to lignin and its oligomeric intermediates is one of the major challenges to rationally describe and control lignin liquefaction reactions. The mechanisms by which solvents and additives impact liquefaction reactions are also poorly understood. Because of this, lignin liquefaction remains an art rather than a science. The main goal of this project is to develop a rational micro-kinetic framework based on detailed micro-kinetic models describing depolymerization and repolymerization reactions and intermediate products removal mechanisms during lignin liquefaction. The practical goal is to use this mathematical model and experimental tools to identify suitable lignin liquefaction strategies in the presence of solvents and acid-base catalysts to maximize mono-phenol production which will facilitate further bio-oil upgrading in existing infrastructure. In addition to training two graduate students the principal investigators plan to host female and underrepresented minority high school students in their laboratories as summer research interns through the Summer Research Opportunity Program at Northwestern University and the Pacific Northwest Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
Humans have evolved in contact with oligomeric molecules derived from the thermal degradation of lignin and cellulose released into the atmosphere as smoke during forest fires. Biomass pyrolysis or other liquefaction schemes also produce these molecules in large quantities for further upgrading via hydrotreatment to transportation fuels. The chemical nature of these oligomers, their behavior during liquefaction and upgrading, and their environmental role are unknown. Advancing our understanding of the chemistry of these molecules is critical to developing new fuels, chemicals for agriculture, pesticides, and drugs. Our project focused on developing a generalized frame, experimental strategies, and databases of new lignin oligomeric molecules to model and analyze lignin liquefaction processes. A general strategy for developing microkinetic models for lignin liquefaction technologies was proposed. We contributed to “Lignomics” by creating a novel method for the stochastic generation of oligomeric lignin structures based on the interpretation of Lignin MALDI–FT‐ICR‐MS. We used the computational stochastic generation of lignin oligomers to generate a molecular library to support the assignment of potential candidate structures to compounds detected during FT‐ICR MS analysis. This approach may also be feasible for other macromolecules beyond lignin. Hybrid poplar milled wood lignin (MWL) was isolated and thoroughly characterized by MALDI Fourier transform-ion cyclotron resonance mass spectrometry (FT-ICR MS). Chemical formulas were assigned to each oligomeric compound detected. The MWL was subjected to vacuum pyrolysis in a modified pyroprobe at different pressures, and the resulting product was analyzed by FT-ICR MS. A new strategy to assign chemical formulas to the oligomeric lignin products was proposed based on plausible pyrolysis reaction mechanisms of depolymerization/fragmentation applied to original MWL oligomer chemical formulas. Our results support the hypothesis that pyrolytic lignin is formed by removing moieties from primary lignin depolymerization products with between three and five aromatic rings. This fragmentation/depolymerization allows the oligomers to reduce their molecular weight to the point where they can be removed from the reaction zone via evaporation. Biomass-derived pyrolytic lignin structures from demethylation reactions were elucidated using density functional theory calculations. We proposed dimer, trimer, and tetramer structures based on their relative thermodynamic stability for a hardwood lignin model in pyrolysis. Different configurations of oligomers were evaluated by varying the positions of the guaiacyl (G) and syringyl (S) units and the bonds βO4 and β5 in the hardwood model lignin through electronic structure calculations. Thermophysical properties were calculated using group contribution methods. The structure and physical properties of pyrolytic sugar oligomers derived from cellulose depolymerization/dehydration reactions were also studied. We used electronic structure calculations to evaluate the relative thermodynamic stabilities of several oligomer species. A library of the thermodynamically favored candidate molecular structures was compiled. A new characterization strategy was developed based on the chromatographic separation of the oligomeric fraction with increased polarity solvents. The resulting fractions were thoroughly characterized, and a representative oligomeric structure for each fraction was proposed. This project advanced our understanding of the chemistry of lignin oligomers and their formation mechanisms during biomass pyrolysis and other liquefaction strategies. Chemical structures for oligomeric molecules of great technological and environmental importance and their thermal formation mechanisms were proposed.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2023
Modified by: Manuel Garcia-Perez
